rComments: Prof Johnson is amazing. Although he doesn't like to provide detailed rubrics for his assignments, he does guide you in order to ensure you succeed. For this class, we were graded on participation (20%), a briefing note (15%), hosting a class (15%) a term paper (50% : either 15% for a presentation + 30% for the paper or entire 50% for paper).

Professor Johnson makes his class into a seminar style rather than a lecture so you should be prepared to make notes and participate in the class and he often likes to get responses and questions from the students. The weekly assignment he provides are not that difficult and relates to the material of the week. He is a solid choice for the class.

Prof Johnson was very good this past semester. He is kind/receptive and enjoys engaging in class discourse covering the topic (governance and non-profits). You have roughly 3-4 readings per week, doing them will be very useful to engage in class/will be used for reference for the term paper + final exam. His slides also relate to core ideas well.

Robert Johnson is a very nice person and a good professor as well. The fact that the subject is rather dry plays against him, but he does a great job at conveying the material. The mid-term was kind of tricky because if you got one answer wrong then it had a cascade effect, but the final exam was open book and within what one would expect.

Considering the dryness of a topic such as Public Policy, I found Johnson's teaching style reasonably effective. I had never taken a PAP course before, so I do not have the same insight on professor quality in regards to the subject, but I found Johnson enthusiastic about teaching the course. However the slides are not useful, attendance mandatory.
Lovely person, albeit he's not a great communicator, and loses himself in tangents too obscure to follow. I genuinely wish him well, but wish he would either not teach.
To do well in this class attendance is mandatory, as his slides are incredibly vague. Very nice guy though but is quite hard to understand when teaching this class.

Assessments are open book, but excruciatingly specific. Professor Johnson is clearly a very nice man, and I want to like him, but the organization of the course is simply too ineffective and boring to recommend.  Unfortunately, skipping class results in major reduction of grades due to participation.  Very nice man, not a great prof.

Johnson is a very smart man but very hard to understand in his explanations about public policy. He literally uses the textbook as a bible and breaches every example from it. Slides are useless and going to class only gives you participation marks. Exams are open book but very hard questions. Avoid at all costs.

I really want to like this prof.  He is very sweet and understanding and has a great personality.  I don't think that he realizes this is an introductory course. He teaches as if we should already know the subject quite well.  Most of us don't, we are in public admin not economics. Needs to work on teaching style. Will not take him again. :(

If there is a way to do well in this class, it is beyond me.  As a student who attends class regularly, I am leaving this course with about as much knowledge of the subject as I had coming in.  Huge mistake to take this class.  AVOID!!!

Excellent professor. Requirements for assignments were clear and the prof marked fairly. Participation is mandatory. He's also a really reasonable an approachable prof. Knows his material and teaches it well. Great class overall!
This teacher is one of the nicest teach in public admin ! If you dislike him well good luck to you on the rest of your major ! He is a smart cookie and funny too !

Small class seen as a seminary, everyone has to discuss (20% of the mark is attendance & participation), not a lot of time allowed for the mid-session essay (2 weeks and 30%) + 2 weeks for takehome final: read your texts regularly OR discuss in class about the general ideas!! It doesn't matter if you've read or not as long as you're there to talk!

I had Professor Johnson for a very small class and so it was quickly apparent that he was a nice guy. For this class you really need to do your readings. He's not an easy marker --but not an incredibly tough one either.
